questions.question:
Question 1: A young man who collapsed at a concert was suspected to have bacterial meningitis. The 
other attendees of the concert were administered ciprofloxacin by the medical staff on duty. 
What is this kind of antimicrobial therapy called?
questions.explanation:
The antimicrobial treatment initiated in a patient who is not yet infected is called prophylactic 
therapy. The goal is to prevent infection in some patients and to prevent dangerous 
manifestations of infections in other patients. Option A: Preemptive therapy is therapy in an asymptomatic individual with evidence of infection 
(high-risk). 415 
Sold by @itachibot Option C: Empirical therapy is broad-spectrum therapy in a patient with symptoms of infection 
but no microbiological confirmation of the causative agent. Option D: Suppressive therapy is given to patients when the infection is controlled but not 
completely eradicated by the initial round of antimicrobial treatment. This is usually indicated for 
immunosuppressed patients.

questions.question:
Question 2: The total microbial population was found to be susceptible to antimicrobials on testing but a 
subset of the same population was resistant which was undetected. What is this phenomenon 
called?
questions.explanation:
Heteroresistance occurs when a subset of the total microbial population is resistant, despite the 
total microbial population being susceptible on testing. The resistant subpopulation is usually well 
below the assay-detection limits. Heteroresistant Staphylococci and M. tuberculosis have led to therapeutic failures and mortality. 
C. albicans and C. neoformans with heteroresistance to fluconazole have resulted in increased 
treatment failures. Note: For viruses, the resistant viral species occurring due to the above phenomenon is termed as 
'quasi-species'. Quasi-species resistant to antiretroviral agents have resulted in the failure of 
antiretroviral therapy.

questions.question: Question 3: Which of the following drugs shows concentration-dependent killing?
questions.explanation:
Aminoglycosides exhibit concentration-dependent killing and are preferably dosed once daily for 
maximum effect. Peak concentration above MIC (minimum inhibitory concentration) matters for certain classes of 
drugs for their antimicrobial action. It is referred to as concentration-dependent killing. The 
period during which the concentration remains above MIC is not relevant for such drugs. 
Aminoglycosides and quinolones have this property. Time-dependent killing: The antimicrobial action is dependent on the period for which the 
concentration of drug remains above the MIC. Penicillins, 5-fluorocytosine and vancomycin have 
this property.

questions.question:
Question 4: 412 
Sold by @itachibot A patient having pneumococcal pneumonia could not be treated using penicillin G as the 
microbe was found to be resistant to it. How is this resistance mainly acquired?
questions.explanation:
Transformation is the molecular basis of penicillin G resistance in pneumococci and 
meningococci.

questions.question: Question 5: What is the extrachromosomal DNA present in bacteria that transmits drug resistance called?
questions.explanation:
Drug resistance transmitting extrachromosomal DNA present in bacteria is a plasmid. 416 
Sold by @itachibot They are usually involved in the horizontal transfer of drug resistance gene in 
bacteria. Chromosomal DNA can also be involved in the transfer of resistance.

questions.question: Question 6: How is multidrug resistance transferred among bacteria?
questions.explanation:
Multidrug resistance is transferred through conjugation. Multiple genes, each encoding for resistance to a drug can be present in a single bacterial cell. 
Typically such genes are present on resistance (R) plasmids. The main mode of transfer of 
resistant gene-containing plasmids is through conjugation.

questions.question:
Question 8: 413 
Sold by @itachibot You want to prescribe a bactericidal drug to a patient having an infection. Which of the 
following drugs will you not choose?
questions.explanation:
Tigecycline is not a bactericidal drug. Tigecycline belongs to a new class of glycylcyclines which is 
a congener of teteracycline . It is a protein synthesis inhibitor and generally considered as a 
bacteriostatic. Isoniazid, daptomycin and ciprofloxacin are all bactericidal agents.

questions.question:
Question 9: A patient developed a surgical site infection with Klebsiella, which is found to be sensitive to a 
cell wall synthesis inhibitor. Which of the following antibiotics is this likely to be?
questions.explanation:
Cefepime is an antibiotic that acts by inhibiting cell wall synthesis. Cefepime is a fourth-generation cephalosporin. Cephalosporins act by inhibiting cell wall 
synthesis. Aminoglycosides, doxycycline, and erythromycin are protein synthesis inhibitors.

questions.question:
Question 10: A patient has presented to your OPD complaining of vomiting and rice water stools. You 
decide to treat him with a protein synthesis inhibitor. Which antibiotic do you choose?
questions.explanation:
417 
Sold by @itachibot Doxycycline is a tetracycline that acts by inhibiting protein synthesis. It is the drug of choice for 
cholera. Options A & D: Cefotetan and oxacillin are beta-lactam antibiotics that act by inhibiting cell 
wall synthesis. Option C: Ciprofloxacin is a fluoroquinolone that acts by inhibiting DNA gyrase.

questions.question: Question 11: Which of the following antibacterial agents does not act by inhibiting cell wall synthesis?
questions.explanation:
Nitrofurantoin is an antibacterial drug that does not act by inhibiting cell wall synthesis. The antibacterial activity of nitrofurantoin appears to correlate with the rapid intracellular 
conversion of nitrofurantoin to highly reactive intermediates by bacterial reductases. These 
intermediates react nonspecifically with many ribosomal proteins and disrupt the synthesis of 
proteins, RNA, DNA, and metabolic processes. Carbapenems, monobactams, and cephalosporins are beta-lactam antibiotics that act by inhibiting 
cell wall synthesis.

questions.question:
Question 12: You are studying the susceptibility of Streptococci to bacitracin in the lab. What is the site of 
action of this drug?
questions.explanation:
Bacitracin acts on the cell wall by inhibiting the synthesis of the cell wall. It interferes with the dephosphorylation of bactoprenol (lipid carrier) which carries peptidoglycan 
subunits outside the cell membrane to the growing cell wall. It can also alter the integrity of the 
cell membrane. Bacitracin is mainly active against gram-positive cocci and bacilli. 418 
Sold by @itachibot Antimalarial Drugs
